sentences.text: A cold snap began in Afghanistan on January 10, 2023. Temperatures reached as low as {{convert|-33|°C|°F}} and snowfall was as high as {{convert|30|cm}} in more mountainous regions. The cold snap killed at least 160 people, making it the Deadliest weather events of 2023|deadliest weather event of 2023 until Cyclone Freddy. Additionally, nearly 80,000 livestock were killed.

references.text: <ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=28 January 2023 |title=Afghanistan cold snap kills over 160, Taliban officials say – DW – 01/28/2023 |url=https://www.dw.com/en/afghanistan-cold-snap-kills-over-160-taliban-officials-say/a-64546879 |access-date=2023-01-30 |website=Deutsche Welle|DW |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Temperatures fell to a low of {{convert|-33|°C|°F}}, with up to {{convert|30|cm}} of snow in the higher mountain altitudes, directly or indirectly killing at least 162 people in various provinces of Afghanistan|provinces. Over 77,000 livestock died due to the weather. Over 50 houses were damaged across the country.

sentences.text: Humanitarian relief efforts provided aid that included heating and relief funds. Supreme leader Hibatullah Akhundzada stated that the restrictions would not be repealed.<ref name="BBC" />

references.text: <ref name=":0" /> Foreign relief efforts were complicated by a ban on women providing humanitarian aid. These restrictions were relaxed for health-related aid on January 17, so non-governmental organizations such as the International Rescue Committee, Save the Children, and Care International resumed operations.<ref name="AJ" /><ref>{{Cite web |date=17 January 2023 |title=NGOs resume some Afghan operations with women workers |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/1/17/ngos-resume-some-operations-with-women-in-afghanistan |access-date=2023-01-24 |website=Al Jazeera Media Network|Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Military helicopters were used to provide relief for citizens cut off by snow, but they were unable to access Afghanistan's mountainous regions.
